text: In a vendor-led ticketing upgrade in transport where audit trails are required and compliance reviews are frequent, what should the project manager do to continually assess effectiveness of artifact management?

options.label: gather feedback on how easily people find information
keep the structure unchanged regardless of feedback
ignore complaints about findability
add new tools without process updates

explanation: Option a is correct because user input reveals effectiveness. Option b is incorrect because stagnant systems may stop working. Option c is incorrect because ignoring issues leaves them unsolved. Option d is incorrect because tool sprawl can worsen management.

text: Given a predictive ticketing upgrade in fintech where teams use multiple tools and security requires access control, which action best supports continually assess effectiveness of artifact management?

options.label: limit access to avoid hearing about problems
measure usage and retrieval times
assess effectiveness only at annual reviews
keep the structure unchanged regardless of feedback

explanation: Option b is correct because metrics show whether management is working. Option a is incorrect because lack of transparency hides issues. Option c is incorrect because infrequent checks miss problems. Option d is incorrect because stagnant systems may stop working.

text: While facing a agile patient portal in public sector where documentation is scattered and compliance reviews are frequent, what is the most effective next step to continually assess effectiveness of artifact management?

options.label: ignore complaints about findability
add new tools without process updates
adjust structure and taxonomy based on lessons learned
limit access to avoid hearing about problems

explanation: Option c is correct because iteration improves usability. Option a is incorrect because ignoring issues leaves them unsolved. Option b is incorrect because tool sprawl can worsen management. Option d is incorrect because lack of transparency hides issues.

text: For a hybrid patient portal in education where teams use multiple tools and sponsors want clear traceability, what should the project manager do first to continually assess effectiveness of artifact management?

options.label: assess effectiveness only at annual reviews
keep the structure unchanged regardless of feedback
ignore complaints about findability
simplify tools or processes if they slow the team

explanation: Option d is correct because effective management should enable work. Option a is incorrect because infrequent checks miss problems. Option b is incorrect because stagnant systems may stop working. Option c is incorrect because ignoring issues leaves them unsolved.

text: In a agile digital campus in transport where teams use multiple tools and knowledge must persist after go-live, what should the project manager do to continually assess effectiveness of artifact management?

options.label: train and onboard people on artifact practices
add new tools without process updates
limit access to avoid hearing about problems
assess effectiveness only at annual reviews

explanation: Option a is correct because education sustains effectiveness. Option b is incorrect because tool sprawl can worsen management. Option c is incorrect because lack of transparency hides issues. Option d is incorrect because infrequent checks miss problems.

text: Given a predictive risk analytics in education where new team members onboard often and handoffs happen monthly, which action best supports continually assess effectiveness of artifact management?

options.label: keep the structure unchanged regardless of feedback
gather feedback on how easily people find information
ignore complaints about findability
add new tools without process updates

explanation: Option b is correct because user input reveals effectiveness. Option a is incorrect because stagnant systems may stop working. Option c is incorrect because ignoring issues leaves them unsolved. Option d is incorrect because tool sprawl can worsen management.
